dt: {bc}the 21st letter of the Greek alphabet {dx}see {dxt|Alphabet Table|alphabet|table}{/dx}

shortdef: the 21st letter of the Greek alphabet

dt: {bc}a person winning high scholastic distinction in an American college or university and being elected to membership in a national honor society founded in 1776

et: {it}Phi Beta Kappa{/it} ({it}Society{/it}), from {it}phi{/it} + {it}beta{/it} + {it}kappa{/it}, initials of the society's Greek motto {it}philosophia biou kybernētēs{/it} philosophy the guide of life
shortdef: a person winning high scholastic distinction in an American college or university and being elected to membership in a national honor society founded in 1776

dt: {bc}apparent motion resulting from an orderly sequence of stimuli (such as lights flashed in rapid succession a short distance apart on a sign) without any actual motion being presented to the eye

et: The term was introduced by the psychologist Max Wertheimer (1880-1943, born in Prague, Austria-Hungary, in the U.S. from 1933) in "Experimentelle Studien über das Sehen von Bewegung," {it}Zeitschrift für Psychologie und Physiologie der Sinnesorgane, 1. Abteilung, Zeitschrift für Psychologie,{/it} Band 61, Heft 1 (April, 1912), pp. 161-265.
shortdef: apparent motion resulting from an orderly sequence of stimuli (such as lights flashed in rapid succession a short distance apart on a sign) without any actual motion being presented to the eye
